explainer.title: 𝑛th Roots: Integers
explainer.seo_meta_description: In this explainer, we will learn how to work out 𝑛th roots of integers, where 𝑛 is a positive integer greater than or equal to 2.

body.p: In this explainer, we will learn how to work out $@n$th roots of integers, where $@n$ is a positive integer greater than or equal to 2.
The $@n$th root of a number is the inverse operation to raising a number to the $@n$th exponent, so we will first review how we find different exponents of a number.
Taking the square root of a number is the inverse operation to raising a number to the second exponent. We can define the square root of a number using the radical symbol $\left(\sqrt{}\right)$.

sidebar.title: Definition: The Square Root of a Number

body.p:
When we consider the square root function, $\sqrt{@x}=@y$, this function takes a positive input $@x$ and returns the positive $@y$-value that would be squared to obtain $@x$. For example,
\begin{align*} \sqrt{25}=5. \end{align*}
We can now investigate what happens when the exponent of a number is an integer greater than 2.
The inverse operations to both of these are the $@n$th roots, where $@n$ represents the value of the exponent.

Note that the radical symbol $\left(\sqrt{}\right)$ is also used for $@n$th roots, and the degree of the radical symbol is the value of $@n$. When the square root is being found, we do not need to write the degree, 2, with the radical symbol. We can define the $@n$th root as follows.

sidebar.title: Definition: 𝑛th Root of a Number

body.p: The 2nd root is usually called the square root. The 3rd root is often called the cube root. After that, the roots are simply the $@n$th root, for example, the 5th root and the 9th root.
It is often useful to make a note of some of the first few exponents of 2, 3, and 4 in order to help us more quickly find the $@n$th roots of these values.

sidebar.title: The First Five Exponents of 2, 3, and 4

body.p: Learning these powers will allow for faster recall and is particularly useful for finding $@n$th roots. For example, to find $\sqrt[5]{243}$, we can use the fact that $3^5=243$ to give the evaluation that $\sqrt[5]{243}=3$.
We can now look at some example questions where we find different $@n$th roots.
We will now see how the fourth root of a value can be evaluated.
In the following example, we will find an unknown value whose square root is equal to the cube root of another number.

body.p: We will now consider finding the $@n$th roots of negative values.
However, both of these give a result of 9, not $-9$. So, neither 3 nor $-3$ is a solution to $\sqrt{-9}$.
Is there a real value $@r$ for which $@r^2=-9$?
If $@r$ is a positive value, then $@r^2 = @r \times @r$ would be a positive multiplied by a positive, giving a positive value. Thus $@r^2 > 0$, and not $-9$.
If $@r$ is a negative value, then $@r^2 = @r \times @r$ would be a negative multiplied by a negative, also giving a positive value, and not $-9$.
Thus, there is no real value of $@x$ for which $@x^2=-9$, and no real solution for $\sqrt{-9}$. In general, there is no real solution for the square root of any negative number.
We can also extend this to any positive, even value of $@n$ in the $@n$th root of a negative number.

ul.li: The $@n$th root of a value is denoted $@r=\sqrt[@n]{@z}$. It is the inverse operation to raising a number to the $@n$th exponent, and we can consider this as finding the value $@r$, such that $@z=@r^@n$.
